text: INTRODUCTION
label: H3

text: This case centers around Complainant’s allegations that Respondent Spring & Soon Fashion
label: BODY

text: Inc. (Spring & Soon) violated the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) by hiring employees
label: BODY

text: knowing they were unauthorized to work in the United States and by failing to comply with the
label: BODY

text: employment eligibility verification requirements of the INA.  Complainant also seeks to hold
label: BODY

text: Respondent Y Plus Corporation d/b/a Y Prus Corporation (Y Plus) responsible for any violations
label: BODY

text: actually committed by Spring & Soon.  The main issues in this Order are:
label: BODY

text: (1)  whether Complainant has demonstrated that there are no genuine issues of
label: BODY

text: material fact in this case; and
label: BODY

text: (2)  whether Complainant has demonstrated that it is entitled to judgment as a matter
label: BODY

text: of law against Spring & Soon and/or Y Plus.
label: BODY

text: This Order disposes of all outstanding motions.  For the reasons discussed in detail below, I find that
label: BODY

text: Complainant has demonstrated that there are no genuine issues of material fact and that it is entitled
label: BODY

text: to judgment as a matter of law as to the liability of both Spring & Soon and Y Plus.  However, I find
label: BODY

text: that Complainant has not demonstrated that there are no genuine issues of material fact with respect
label: BODY

text: to the amount of penalty this case warrants.  As a result, I
label: BODY

text: (1)  GRANT Complainant’s Motion for Summary Decision1 as to liability for both
label: BODY

text: Spring & Soon and Y Plus; and
label: BODY

text: (2)  DENY Complainant’s Motion for Summary Decision as to the appropriate civil
label: BODY

text: money penalty to assess.
label: BODY

text: III.
label: HH3

text: STANDARDS FOR SUMMARY DECISION
label: H3

text: The Rules of Practice and Procedure that govern this proceeding permit the Administrative
label: BODY

text: Law Judge (ALJ or Judge) to “enter a summary decision for either party if the pleadings, affidavits,
label: BODY

text: material  obtained  by  discovery  or  otherwise,  or  matters  officially  noticed  show  that  there  is
label: BODY

text: no genuine issue as to any material fact and that a party is entitled to summary decision.”  28 C.F.R.
label: BODY

text: § 68.38(c) (1996).  Although OCAHO has its own procedural rules for cases arising under its
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction, the OCAHO Rules of Practice specifically authorize the Judge to reference analogous
label: BODY

text: provisions  of  the  Federal  Rules  of  Civil  Procedure  and  federal  case  law  interpreting  them
label: BODY

text: for  guidance  in  deciding  issues  based  on  the  rules  governing  OCAHO  proceedings.  OCAHO
label: BODY

text: Rule 68.38(c) is similar to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56(c), which provides for summary
label: BODY

text: judgment in cases before the federal district courts.  As such, Rule 56(c) and federal case law
label: BODY

text: interpreting it are useful in deciding whether summary decision is appropriate under the OCAHO
label: BODY

text: rules.  United States v. Aid Maintenance Co., 6 OCAHO 893, at 3 (1996), 1996 WL 73594, at *35
label: BODY

text: (Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Complainant’s Motion for Partial Summary

text: An issue of material fact is genuine if it has a “real basis in the record.”  Tri Component, 5 OCAHO

label: BODY

text: moving party.”  Id. (citing Matsushita, 475 U.S. at 587 and Primera, 4 OCAHO at 261, 1994 WL
label: BODY

text: The party requesting summary decision carries the initial burden of demonstrating the
label: BODY

text: absence of any genuine issues of material fact.  Id. (citing Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317,
label: BODY

text: 323 (1986)).  Additionally, the moving party has the burden of showing that it is entitled to judgment
label: BODY

text: as a matter of law.  United States v. Alvand, Inc., 1 OCAHO 1958, 1959 (Ref. No. 296) (1991), 1991
label: BODY

text: WL 717207, at *2 (Decision and Order Granting in Part and Denying in Part Complainant’s Motion
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 1987)).  After the moving party has met its burden, “the opposing party must then come forward with
label: BODY

text: ‘specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue for trial.’” Tri Component, 5 OCAHO at 768,
label: BODY

text: 1995 WL 813122, at *2 (quoting Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(e)).  The party opposing summary decision may
label: BODY

text: not “rest upon conclusory statements contained in its pleadings.”  Alvand, 1 OCAHO at 1959, 1991
label: BODY

text: WL 717207, at *2 (citing Nilsson, Robbins, Dalgarn, Berliner, Carson & Wurst v. Louisiana
label: BODY

text: Hydrolec, 854 F.2d 1538 (9th Cir. 1988)).  The Rules of Practice and Procedure governing OCAHO
label: BODY

text: Complainant’s  Motion for Summary Decision is based largely on the answers deemed
label: BODY

text: admitted to its Request for Admissions.  Requests for admissions are deemed admitted if not
label: BODY

text: responded to within thirty days of service.  See 28 C.F.R. § 68.21(b) (1997); see also Fed. R. Civ.
label: BODY

text: P. 36(a).7   If  the  requests  for  admission  are  served  by  ordinary  mail,  the  responding party has
label: BODY

text: five additional days in which to serve its answers and/or objections.  See 28 C.F.R. § 68.8(c)(2)
label: BODY

text: (1997).  The requests automatically are deemed admitted if the party from whom the admissions are
label: BODY

text: sought does not respond within the appropriate time limit.  See Beberaggi v. New York City Transit
label: BODY

text: Auth., No. 93 Civ. 1737 (SWK), 1994 WL 18556, at *2 (S.D.N.Y. Jan. 19, 1994) (citing, inter alia,
label: BODY

text: Donovan v. Carls Drug Co., 703 F.2d 650, 651 (2d Cir. 1983)); American Technology Corp. v. Mah,
label: BODY

text: 174  F.R.D.  687,  690  (D. Nev. 1997).  A  motion  to  deem  the  requests  admitted  is  not
label: BODY

text: necessary.  See Beberaggi, 1994 WL 18556, at *2; Mah, 174 F.R.D. at 690 (denying a motion to
label: BODY

text: deem requests for admissions admitted on the grounds that it was unnecessary, given the automatic
label: BODY

text: effect of Rule 36(a)).

label: BODY

text: F. Supp. 42, 46 n.2 (S.D.N.Y. 1996) (treating party’s request that its responses to requests for

label: BODY

text: opponent’s motion for summary judgment, as a formal Rule 36(b) motion when, among other things,

text: the grounds upon which the requested relief was sought were “clearly set forth” in the affirmation).
label: BODY

text: The OCAHO Rules of Practice provide no standard for permitting the withdrawal and/or
label: BODY

text: amendment of admissions made in the context of requests for admissions.  The Federal Rules of
label: BODY

text: Civil Procedure, however, provide such a standard.8  See Fed. R. Civ. P. 36(b).  Under the Federal
label: BODY

text: Rules, the trial judge “may permit withdrawal or amendment when the presentation of the merits of
label: BODY

text: the action will be subserved thereby and the party who obtained the admission fails to satisfy the
label: BODY

text: court that withdrawal or amendment will prejudice that party in maintaining the action or defense
label: BODY

text: on the merits.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 36(b) (emphasis added).  “[T]he decision to excuse [a party] from
label: BODY

text: its admissions is in the court’s discretion.”  Donovan v. Carls Drug Co., Inc., 703 F.2d 650, 651-52
label: BODY

text: (2d Cir. 1983).  “Because the language of the Rule is permissive, the court is not required to make
label: BODY

text: an exception to Rule 36 even if both the merits and prejudice issues cut in favor of the party seeking
label: BODY

text: exception to the rule.”  Id. at 652; see also American Express Travel Related Servs. Co., Inc. v.
label: BODY

text: Ladouceur (In re Ladouceur), No. 95-CV-271 (RSP), 1996 WL 596718, at *3 (N.D.N.Y. Oct. 15,
label: BODY

text: 1996); O’Neill v. Medad, 166 F.R.D. 19, 22 (E.D. Mich. 1996) (citing Ropfogel v. United States,
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: In the Response to the SCO, Respondents’ attorney, Raymond Aab, gave several reasons for
label: BODY

text: failing to respond to Complainant’s Request for Admissions in a timely manner.  Mr. Aab stated that
label: BODY

text: he was unable to respond to Complainant’s discovery requests sooner because “[t]he requests were
label: BODY

text: quite voluminous and the respondent’s principal and person assisting in obtaining the requested
label: BODY

text: documents and answers to the discovery requests, Mr. Sung, was unable to obtain much of the
label: BODY

text: requested documents until May 19th.”  R. Response SCO ¶ 3(a).  Mr. Aab also stated the “process
label: BODY

text: was rendered more problematic, because Mr. Sung speaks only halting English and he needed to
label: BODY

text: return to [Respondents’ counsel’s] office three time to assist in the preparation of the respondents’
label: BODY

text: responses to the discovery requests before he fully understood.”  Id.  Additionally, Mr. Aab stated
label: BODY

text: that he was engaged in  a  three-week criminal  trial  that  “concerned  allegations  of  fraud  and
label: BODY

text: involved  very  complicated  issues and facts,” and that his “time was virtually fully occupied with
label: BODY

text: that trial,” which did not end until 5:30 p.m. on May 19.  Id. ¶ 3(b).  Mr. Aab, however, did not
label: BODY

text: explain why he did not seek relief from the Court to expand the deadline to respond to
label: BODY

text: Complainant’s discovery requests.
label: BODY

text: Respondents have not shown good cause for failing to respond to Complainant’s Request for
label: BODY

text: Admissions in a timely manner or for failing to request an extension of time in which to respond.
label: BODY

text: As of May 20, the date on the Response, Mr. Aab stated that he had “been engaged in a criminal trial
label: BODY

text: and proceedings . . . for the past three weeks.”  Id.  Given that time frame, Mr. Aab’s trial would
label: BODY

text: have started sometime in the last week of April.  Respondents’ response to the Request for
label: BODY

text: Admissions was due April 17.  Mr. Aab’s trial did not begin until more than one week after the
label: BODY

text: response was due.  The fact that a trial monopolized Mr. Aab’s time for the three weeks between the
label: BODY

text: last week in April and May 20 explains nothing about why Mr. Aab failed to respond to
label: BODY

text: Complainant’s Request for Admissions by the middle of April.  Mr. Aab could have asked for an
label: BODY

text: extension of time, but he did not.
label: BODY

text: The need to answer other discovery requests also did not excuse Respondents’ obligation to
label: BODY

text: respond to Complainant’s Request for Admissions.  Mr. Aab cited a delay in the ability to obtain
label: BODY

text: requested documents as a reason for failing to respond to Complainant’s discovery requests in a
label: BODY

text: timely fashion.  See id. ¶ 3(a).  Any delay in obtaining the necessary documents, however, did not
label: BODY

text: justify a delay in responding to the Request for Admissions.
label: BODY

text: Complainant’s Request for Admissions was not voluminous.  When Respondents finally
label: BODY

text: responded to the requests, they denied most of them.  Respondents did not need two months to
label: BODY

text: answer the Request for Admissions.
label: BODY

text: Finally, Respondents did not bother to respond to Complainant’s Request for Admissions
label: BODY

text: until prompted by my May 8 SCO.  Not only did Mr. Aab let the deadline for responding to the
label: BODY

text: Request pass, but he persisted in his lack of attention and action when Complainant filed its Motion
label: BODY

text: for Summary Decision, which was based in large part on the admitted requests.  The Motion notified
label: BODY

text: Respondents’ counsel that Complainant was seeking judgment based on the matters admitted when
label: BODY

text: Respondents failed to answer the Request for Admissions by the deadline.  Despite the seriousness
label: BODY

text: of this action, Respondents’ counsel did not immediately answer the Request and move to permit

label: BODY

text: Respondents to withdraw and to amend their admissions.  Not only did Respondents fail to act with

label: BODY

text: Courts have concluded there are situations in which it would not “further the interests of
label: BODY

text: justice” to “deem a central fact to have been admitted by the failure of [a] pro se defendant to
label: BODY

text: respond” to requests for admissions.  See Local Union No. 38, Sheet Metal Workers’ Int’l Ass’n,
label: BODY

text: AFL-CIO v. Tripodi, 913 F. Supp. 290, 294 (S.D.N.Y. 1996).  I generally agree with that philosophy,
label: BODY

text: but that factual scenario is not the situation in this case.  Respondents are represented by an attorney
label: BODY

text: whose duty it is to advise them in legal matters and actively pursue their interests within the bounds
label: BODY

text: of the law.  Allowing Respondents to withdraw and amend their admissions under the present
label: BODY

text: circumstances would itself work an injustice by rewarding the glaring disregard of rules designed
label: BODY

text: to promote fairness and efficiency in the legal process.  Cf. Alexander v. Commissioner of Internal
label: BODY

text: Revenue, 926 F.2d 197, 199 (2d Cir. 1991) (stating, in the context of affirming the trial court’s
label: BODY

text: decisions not to permit the late filing of answers to the requests for admissions and to grant summary
label: BODY

text: judgment based on matters deemed admitted, that “[i]t is not the role of appellate courts to make
label: BODY

text: allowances for the patent disregard of clearly stated trial court rules that are in part designed to
label: BODY

text: provide for the expeditious conclusion of litigation”).  All the matters about which Complainant
label: BODY

text: sought admissions in its Request for Admissions were admitted when Respondents failed to respond
label: BODY

text: to the Request in a timely manner; all those items deemed admitted stay admitted.
label: BODY

text: Respondents did not answer the Request for Admissions in time, and, when they did answer,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Rule  36  was  amended  in  1970  to  resolve  a  conflict “in the court decisions as to whether
label: BODY

text: a  request to admit matters of ‘opinion’ and matters involving ‘mixed law and fact’ is proper under
label: BODY

text: the rule.”  Fed. R. Civ. P. 36 advisory committee’s note.  Rule 36 now states that requests for
label: BODY

text: admissions  may  “relate  to  statements  or  opinions  of  fact  or  of  the  application  of  law  to
label: BODY

text: fact,”  Fed.  R.  Civ. P. 36(a), thereby “eliminat[ing] the requirement that the matters be ‘of fact,’”
label: BODY

text: see Fed. R. Civ. P. 36 advisory committee’s note.
label: BODY

text: 8 OCAHO 1003
label: BODY

text: 9  Some post-1970 cases still say that requests that call for legal conclusions, even in
label: BODY

text: relation to the facts of the case, or that go to central facts in dispute are improper.  See, e.g.,
label: BODY

text: Whitaker v. Belt Concepts of America, Inc. (In re Olympia Holding Corp.), 189 B.R. 846, 853
label: BODY

text: (Bankr. M.D. Fla. 1995).  Those cases, however, cite to pre-1970 case law, or to other post-1970
label: BODY

text: cases that cite to pre-1970 case law, in support of their position.
label: BODY

text: Requests that call for a pure conclusion of law are improper, but requests that ask for a
label: BODY

text: conclusion of law in relation to the facts of the actual case at hand are acceptable.  See Abbott v.
label: BODY

text: United States, 177 F.R.D. 92, 93 (N.D.N.Y. 1997); Fed. R. Civ. P. 36 advisory committee’s note
label: BODY

text: (“The amended provision does not authorize requests for admissions of law unrelated to the facts
label: BODY

text: of the case.”); see also Audiotext Communications Network, Inc. v. US Telecom, Inc., No. Civ. A.
label: BODY

text: No. 94-2395-GTV, 1995 WL 625744, at *6 (D. Kan. 1995) (requests that seek application of law
label: BODY

text: to the facts of the case are acceptable).  Allowing requests that call for conclusions of law in relation
label: BODY

text: to the facts of the case meets the Rule 36 objective of narrowing the disputed issues in the case.  See
label: BODY

text: Fed. R. Civ. P. 36 advisory committee’s note (“An admission of a matter involving the application
label: BODY

text: of law to fact may, in a given case, even more clearly narrow the issues.”); Leviton Mfg., 94 F.R.D.
label: BODY

text: at 35-36.  In a related vein, “[t]here is nothing improper about a request simply because it goes to
label: BODY

text: an ultimate fact that may be dispositive of the case . . . .”  Hart v. Dow Chemical, No. 95 C 1811
label: BODY

text: In Abbott, a party requested admissions of law that were based exclusively on hypothetical
label: BODY

text: facts given in the requests.  See Abbott, 177 F.R.D. at 93.  The court ruled that such requests were
label: BODY

text: improper:
label: BODY

text: Although admittedly the boundary line is not always plain between
label: BODY

text: permissible questions relating to the application of law to fact and objectionable
label: BODY

text: questions relating to pure questions of law, the questions posed by plaintiff in this
label: BODY

text: case fall outside the bounds of proper discovery.  Most telling is that plaintiffs have
label: BODY

text: not posed proper questions requiring application of law to the facts peculiar to this
label: BODY

text: case to clarify the government’s legal theories; rather, plaintiffs have posed improper
label: BODY

text: hypothetical factual scenarios unrelated to the facts here to ascertain answers to pure
label: BODY

text: questions of law.  This they cannot do.
label: BODY

text: Id.
label: BODY

text: In the present case, Complainant has not posed requests for admissions based on hypothetical
label: BODY

text: scenarios.  The requests regarding Y Plus’ status as a successor in interest to and mere continuation
label: BODY

text: of Spring & Soon involve conclusions of law, but in relation to the facts of this case.  That is
label: BODY

text: something Rule 36 clearly permits since its 1970 amendment.9

text: To rule on Complainant’s Motion for Summary Decision, I must examine whether
label: BODY

text: Complainant has demonstrated a lack of genuine issue of material fact and is entitled to judgment
label: BODY

text: as a matter of law.  “[I]t is well settled that a failure to respond to a request for admissions will
label: BODY

text: permit the district court to enter summary judgment if the facts admitted by operation of Rule 36(a)
label: BODY

text: are dispositive of the case.”  Pleasant Hill Bank v. United States, 60 F.R.D. 1 (W.D. Mo. 1973)
label: BODY

text: (citing, inter alia, Moosman v. Blitz, Inc., 358 F.2d 686, 688 (2d Cir. 1966)); see also Donovan v.
label: BODY

text: Carls Drug Co., Inc., 703 F.2d 650, 651 (2d Cir. 1983).  “[A]dmissions under Rule 36, even those
label: BODY

text: made upon a party’s default in responding, may serve as the factual predicate for summary
label: BODY

text: judgment.”  Pakistan Int’l Airlines v. Travel Link Int’l, Ltd., No. 90 CIV. 1703 (PNL), 1991 WL
label: BODY

text: 130182, at *2 (S.D.N.Y. July 9, 1991) (citing Carls Drug, 703 F.2d at 651).

text: A first-time violator of the knowing hire provision under 8 U.S.C. § 1324a(1)(A) shall
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: has been subject to one order for a knowing hire or continue to employ violation, the INA mandates
label: BODY

text: a cease and desist order and a civil money penalty of not less than $2,000 and not more than $5,000
label: BODY

text: for each unauthorized alien knowingly hired.  See id. § 1324a(e)(4)(A)(ii).

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: however, then the total requested penalty would be $31,080.
